generic: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Poliovirus, and Hib Vaccine
drugs: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Poliovirus, and Hib Vaccine

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Poliovirus, and Hib Vaccine

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in children 5 years of age or older
  • Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hemophilus influenzae type B infection, Invasive; Prophylaxis: (6 weeks to less than 5 years of age) primary series, 0.5 mL IM x 4 doses given at 2, 4, 6, and 15 to 18 months of age
  • Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hemophilus influenzae type B infection, Invasive; Prophylaxis: upon completion of the 4-dose series of Pentacel(R), administer a fifth dose of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, adsorbed, and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) at 4 to 6 years of age; use of Daptacel(R) for DTaP is recommended due to similarity of pertussis antigens
  • Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hemophilus influenzae type B infection, Invasive; Prophylaxis: administer with an appropriate antipyretic and for 24 hours following vaccination in patients with a history of previous seizures
  • Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hemophilus influenzae type B infection, Invasive; Prophylaxis: the same brand of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, adsorbed, and acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) vaccine should be used for all doses in the vaccination series, whenever feasible

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus triple and polio vaccination - Hemophilus influenzae type B infection, Invasive; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• age less than 6 weeks
  • encephalopathy (eg, coma, decreased levels of consciousness, prolonged seizures) within 7 days of a previous dose of pertussis not attributable to other causes
  • progressive neurologic disorder (eg, infantile spasms, uncontrolled epilepsy, progressive encephalopathy); contraindicated until neurologic status is stabilized
  • severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to previous dose of vaccine combination, any vaccine component, or product ingredient

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • anaphylactic or acute hypersensitivity reactions may occur
  • brachial neuritis may occur with administration of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccination
  • collapse or shock-like state (hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode) occurring within 48 hours of any pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • crying, persistent, inconsolable; duration of at least 3 hours occurring within 48 hours of any pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • fever, (105 degrees F or 40.5 degrees C or higher) occurring within 48 hours of any pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome occurring within 6 weeks of any tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine; increased risk of recurrence; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • hypersensitivity reaction, arthus-type, after a previous tetanus-toxoid-containing vaccine; defer vaccination until at least 10 years since last tetanus-toxoid-containing vaccine
  • lack of immune response to vaccine may occur in some patients, especially if immunosuppressed
  • pregnancy; can be administered if there is a risk for exposure to wild-type poliovirus infection
  • premature infants; apnea has been observed following intramuscular vaccination; consider medical status and risk/benefits prior to administration
  • revaccination in patients with unknown vaccination history; after the fourth and fifth DTaP dose an increased rate of adverse events may occur; serologic testing may be indicated
  • seizure history; an antipyretic medication, given at the time of vaccination and for 24 hours post-vaccination, may reduce risk of post-vaccination fever
  • seizure, with or without fever, occurring within 3 days of any pertussis-containing vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk prior to administration
  • report adverse events to VAERS 1-800-822-7967, or http://www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (7.1% to 17.3%), Injection site pain (39.2% to 56.1%), Swelling at injection site (5% to 9.7%)
  • Neurologic:Lethargy (24.1% to 45.8%)
  • Psychiatric:Crying, inconsolable (35.9% to 59.3%), Irritability (53.5% to 76.9%)
  • Other:Fever (5.8% to 16.3%), Increase in circumference, arm (33.6%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Collapse, hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction, severe
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Diphtheria: Following IM injection, diphtheria toxoid induces the formation of neutralizing antibodies to diphtheria toxin.
  • Tetanus: Following IM injection, tetanus toxoid induces the formation of neutralizing antibodies to tetanus toxin.
  • Pertussis: Following IM injection, acellular pertussis vaccine induces the formation of several antibodies thought to be clinically protective. The levels of antibody necessary for protection have not been determined.
  • Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine (IPV): Following IM injection, IPV induces the production of neutralizing antibodies against each poliovirus serotype correlating with protection against poliomyelitis.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    For IM use only; do not administer IV or subQ
  • Intramuscular
    • add the component of diphtheria and tetanus toxoid, acellular pertussis, and inactivated poliovirus to the Haemophilus b conjugate component
    • combined suspension will be cloudy, white to off-white color with a yellow tinge
    • administer immediately upon reconstitution
    • in infants younger than 1 year, anterolateral aspect of thigh is preferred site of injection; deltoid muscle may be used in older children
    • do not inject in gluteal area(s) or areas where there may be a major nerve trunk
    • use separate syringes and site when administering concomitantly with other vaccines

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: signs/symptoms of hypersensitivity to acellular pertussis component of vaccine

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Pentacel
KIT: (Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed - Pertussis Vaccine, Acellular - Poliovirus Vaccine, Inactivated - Tetanus Toxoid;Haemophilus B Conjugate VaccineDiphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed - Pertussis Vaccine, Acellular - Poliovirus Vaccine, Inactivated - Tetanus Toxoid;Haemophilus B Conjugate Vaccine) 15 Lf U/0.5 ML,10 MCG,48 MCG/0.5 ML,80 D Antigen U/0.5 ML,5 Lf U/0.5 ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause injection site reactions, decreased activity, lethargy, fussiness, irritability, dehydration, gastroenteritis, bronchiolitis, asthma, and pneumonia.
  • Instruct parent or caregiver to report a temperature of 40.5 degrees Celsius (105 degrees Fahrenheit) or higher; persistent, inconsolable crying lasting 3 hours or more; or collapse or a shock-like state (hypotonic, hyporesponsive) within 48 hours of injection.
  • Instruct parent or caregiver to report a seizure with or without fever that occurs within 3 days of injection.
  • Inform caregiver of the importance of the child receiving the entire series of vaccinations in the absence of contraindications. If a dose is missed, another appointment should be scheduled as soon as possible.
